name: senna-marilandica
distribution: From Massachusetts and New York to the south of Florida
wildlife-value: Bumblebees are attracted to pollen. Birds enjoy the seeds particularly quail and dove. Larval host plant of various types of Sulphur butterflies. Insects like ladybird beetles, ants and flies eat the nectar at the glands found at the base of the petioles because the flowers are nectar-less.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Flattened pods 4" long 1/2" wide, dark brown at maturity with 10-18 segments each containing a seed.
flower-description: Butter yellow, not typical pea-like flowers, raceme or panicle of flowers 1/2"-1" long.  Flowers have 5 yellow sepals, 5 yellow petals, 10 dark brown stamens.  Petals whiten as they age from mid- to late summer.  There is no floral scent.
leaf-description: The dull green leaves are pinnate and composed of 6-12 pairs of oval leaflets.
stem-description: Light green stout central stem, slightly hairy in the upper stem
uses: In the 9th century, Arab physicians used to brew the leaves to make a cathartic tea. The leaves and seeds are used today as a laxative. The Cherokee and other peoples use the root of the plant to treat high fevers, a worm remedy, treat fainting spells and to treat pneumonia.
